ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Study groups
there were a few recorded clips that were required for viewing before class
Zoom, canvas, and piazza
The lectures are also recorded.
There were also videos that were pre recorded which we watched before class
recorded lecture + in-person class
Although the class was a live virtual lecture, all classes were recorded. If a student missed class, there were many opportunities to go to office hours.
There was a bit of discussion format type work when we worked in breakout rooms. We also answered questions in chat. This class was not completely just a lecture but a bit of each.
None.
Also recorded lectures for those who could not make it to certain classes. Office hours could make up PPP points if student could not make it to a class.
Preclass assignments, office hours

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned the essential of calculus, including limits, derivatives, and integrals and how to use them in the context of problem solving.
I developed the skills to do calculus and mathematical practice standards of showing all the work and steps it took to get there. I also learned perseverance.
I learned different derivation skills
Math, calculus
I became better at finding new ways to solve problems.
Some higher level understanding of calculus
Basic Calculus.
I learned how to do basic differentiation and integration, as well as how to think / write mathematically sound arguments.
There was a major focus on differentiation, followed by topics on integration. Introduction to calculus (similar to that of AP Calc AB) but learned through theorems.
Calculus 1 fundamentals: derivatives, integration

I didn't learn any new calculus as I had taken calc 1 in high school, but it did retouch on a lot of the subjects I have since forgotten. Overall I think there were a lot of materials on the HAMs and PSETS that were never taught in the class. However, being able to practice mastery 4+ times helped a lot.
I learned how to apply many of the concepts in this class across different problems.

I learned Calculus I: theorems, formulas, algebra improvement, and various methods of calculation. The mastery-based system requires that a lot of attention be paid to articulation in problem sets, which is a boon to writing ability.
I learned alot about Calculus.
I applied the topics learned to solve differential calculus problems.
We went over similar material to AP Calc AB
Knowledge of principles of single variable calculus, calculus applications to the real world .

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: A strength in this course was we were able to sometimes collaborate with our peers in order to understand the material. A weakness of this course was the fact that it was online, and so it was difficult to make connections with other students in order to help each other. Additionally, there was a lot of work involved with this class, and so I often found myself approaching the deadline to an assignment and still having a mountain of work to do.

Strengths: great camaraderie among students, well-structured course, pre-class assignments were helpful in getting exposed to the material.
Weaknesses: expectations were a bit confusing at the  beginning in terms of how the professor wanted the work to be done to earn full points.
Sometimes the material was a little hard to grasp during the zoom sessions, or at least how to apply it to the problem sets, but the teacher always had office hours that were very helpful.

Strengths: grading style, professor engagement/accesibility
Weaknesses: didn't thoroughly explain some topics, didn't stay on topic during lecture, quizzes often didn't match up w taught material

One of the strengths of this course was that there was no "graded" tests and that it is a mastery based system, so it wasn't as stressful to get the grade that I wanted. On the other hand, it doesn't keep me as accountable about my grade, and I could feel myself slacking due the the fact that there was no strict grading system.
The weakness of this course is that many people are taking it because they have to. That aside, the course itself was amazingProf. Barnes and the mastery system made it really shine.

The strengths of this course were that grades were determined by mastery standards, so students didn't have to worry about immediately learning a topic. Personally, I preferred a mastery based system over regular grading because you aren't penalized for not fully grasping concepts early on, so you have more time to process the material. Also, office hours with peer tutors are extremely helpful (shoutout to Kexin!) The weaknesses of this course were that sometimes grading wasn't all that clear (I would recommend taking the class with James Barnes given that he determines the structure of all Math 112 classes) and that quizzes sometimes differed from what was taught in class.

Strengths: Multiple attempts to achieve mastery alleviated stress on midterms or finals. P-sets were graded on participation.

Weaknesses: The mastery system was very confusing and not straightforward, which made knowing our current grade incredibly difficult.

The course layout is very clear and there is lots of transparency regarding how to get the grades you want. I think that the course load was not too much and that homework, class, and preclass assignments were all very manageable but sometimes I just did not feel like I had learned what was being asked of me and when I did make mistakes there was never a clear explanation as to what went wrong.

The strength is that the instructor made himself available to students at many different times and would work with the students to figure out a different time if needed. Something that could be improved is changing how students learn from their attempts at mastering standards. After receiving a score, students would have to directly ask the instructor for each assignment if they wanted to see the correct method of solving. It would have been nice to have had any type of answer key to look over and compare ourselves.
The mastery-based system is a strength in my view! Unfortunately, I felt the class moved much too fast at times.
Nothing this class was great Prof. Barnes is awesome and he really cares about his students.

The mastery system was a definitive strength of the course: it contributed to my collection of calculus skills and wasn't overly stressful. I felt like I would have felt uneccesary pressure and retained less material if it were not a mastery system.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The screen sharing/screen annotating was awesome for virtual engagement this year. I also loved how our professor shared the worksheet with us prior to class, and so we were able to annotate WITH him as we worked.

Succeeded: study groups in breakout rooms, having the worksheets in dark mode
Could be improved: I think a shared google calendar with all the assessment due dates would be helpful because it was overwhelming to remember at times

I think the teacher near the end of the semester notice the effectiveness of breakout rooms and how sometimes they are just a waste of time and other times they aren't. I also loved how he used piazza and got back to the students quite quickly.
Succeess: live lecture kept me more engaged than if it had been asynchronous
This class adapted extremely well to the pandemic situation, and the recorded lecture / online quizzes were especially helpful.

I appreciated the fact that Professor Barnes acknowledged the difficulties of virtual learning. He was understanding of the fact that sometimes we could not make it to class and was open about mental health issues. I also liked how he was flexible about assignments and going to class during election week (something my other professors didn't mention) given that this presidential election was anxiety-inducing especially to students of underrepresented backgrounds.

The professor did an amazing job of respecting the student's time and boundaries. He asked pronouns, gave mental health days, understood that I didn't always want a camera on my face, and that zoom fatigue is very much real. I would say that the student-organized zoom study groups were the most helpful for understanding more than the actual class.

It was ok for the situation but not ideal in any way. It was very difficult learning in this format. Everything feels disconnected and it was harder to work with peers or even meet them. If this course continues in this format more engagement could improve the experience.
Having lectures be recorded is an enormous advantage to online learning. However, I did not enjoy the breakout room function whatsoever.
Everything was great. Kexin for peer tutoring was outstanding.
The flipped classroom I thought was very successful
Overall, I appreciated the course practices. I wouldn't change anything as far as course organization given the circumstances.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, I would recommend this course to another student, but only if their calculus skills need brushing up on. If I were learning this subject material for the first time, I think I would be very confused (lucky for me, I took calculus AB in high school, so I had previously learned the material).
I would recommend this course to another student either for a QR credit or for a way to learn calculus at Yale. It is very structured and fosters collaborative networks among students.
Yes!

Yes, I really liked the mastery system of grading in this course. Unlike other courses it lets students have multiple chances to improve and allows them to focus more on learning and understanding the content.
Yes, I think with a background of at least one calculus class it was a solid course to take and build on previous understanding
Yes, because the teacher was very helpful and the course was relatively simple.
I would if they need to learn this material. The teaching / support is high quality, and the mastery grading system makes yoou feel like you're actually gaining skills.
I would recommend this course because it is a good introduction to calculus.
Yes, if they need to learn the foundation of calculus.
If you need to take this course, I don't think that you really have a choice considering that it's a prerequisite for higher-level math classes.
If they need the course for a requirement by all means yes, take the course. I feel that the instructors did they best that they could given the curent COVID situation.
Yes, it is a great way to complete the Calculus I prerequisite.
Yes, if you really want to learn calculs take this class.
Yes, the professor was great and very understanding.
Yes I would recommend it if you need a basis for more calc classes
I would recommend this course as a means to build basic calculus skills.
